I agree, a parallel directory structure for test code is probably best.
Som=
e reasons to prefer this layout can be found here:

http://www.exubero.com/=
junit/antipatterns.html#Mixing_Production_and_Test_Code

In Eclipse, you ca=
n just right click on the top level test directory, and
select Run As... ->=
 JUnit test. Eclipse will then find all test classes
underneath that direct=
ory and run them. I imagine other IDEs have similar
functionality.

To run =
tests from Ant, you can use the JUnit batchtest runner, which you
can use t=
o select tests based on naming conventions. For example:

  <batchtest fork=
=3D"yes" todir=3D"${reports.tests}">
    <fileset dir=3D"${src.tests}">
   =
   <include name=3D"**/*Test*.java"/>
      <exclude name=3D"**/AllTests.ja=
va"/>
    </fileset>
  </batchtest>

You can find an example of some workin=
g Ant scripts demonstrating this at
http://www.exubero.com/asl/

Cheers,
JO=
e
